[[Image:Bagrat Shinkuba.jpg|thumb|Bagrat Shinkuba on a 1999 stamp of Abkhazia]] [[File:Abkhazia 10 apsar Ag 2009 Shinkuba b.jpg|thumb|Reverse side of a 10 [[Abkhazian apsar|apsar]] [[commemorative coin]] minted in 2009 featuring Bagrat Shinkuba]] '''Bagrat Uasyl-ipa Shinkuba''' ({{lang-ab|Баграҭ Уасыл-иҧа Шьынқәба}}; {{lang-ru|Баграт Васильевич Шинкуба}}; 12 May 1917 in Chlou, [[Ochamchira District]], [[Sukhum Okrug]], [[Kutais Governorate]] – 25 February 2004) was an Abkhaz writer, poet, historian, linguist and politician. He studied history and languages of [[Abkhaz people|Abkhaz]], [[Adyghe people|Adyghe]] and [[Ubykh people|Ubykh]] people. His novel ''The Last of the Departed'' is dedicated to the tragic destiny of Ubykh nation, which became extinct along a hundred of years.
In 1958—1978 he was the Chairman of the Supreme Council Presidium of the [[Abkhaz Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic|Abkhaz ASSR]].
According to Jumber Patiashvili, in 1947 Shinkuba sent a letter "to Kremlin, requesting from Stalin and Beria separation of Abkhazia from Georgia and awarding it the status of an independent republic."<ref>http://www.geworld.ge/View.php?ArtId=2857</ref>
==Works== * [http://www.circassianlibrary.org/lib/html/Shinkuba-The_Last_of_the_Departed/contents.html Bagrat Shinkuba. ''The Last of the Departed'' on Adyghe Library] * Иалкаау иоымтакуа, т. 1—2, Akya, 1967—68; в рус. пер. — Избранное. [Предисл. К. Симонова], М., 1976.

[[File:Histoire anecdote de la Cour de Rome.tif|thumb|''Histoire anecdote de la Cour de Rome'', 1704]]
'''Casimir Freschot''' (1640? – October 20, 1720) was a [[France|French]] [[historian]], [[chronicler]] and [[translator]]. He was the author of about fifty works, both in [[French language|French]], [[Italian language|Italian]] and [[Latin]] on various historical and contemporary subjects, the most notable being ''Li pregi della Nobiltà Veneta abbozzati in un giuoco d'arme'', published in [[Venice]] in 1682, ''Origine, progressi e ruina del calvinismo nella Francia, ragguaglio istorico di D. Casimiro Freschot'', published in 1693, and ''Histoire du congrès et de la paix d'Utrecht - par C. Freschot'', published in 1716.<ref>[http://www.idref.fr/031154492 idRef ]</ref><ref>''Bibliothèque générale des écrivains de l'Ordre de Saint Benoit, patriarche des moines d'Occident: contenant une notice exacte des ouvrages de tout genre, composés par les religieux des diverses branches,...'' Société typographique, 1777</ref>
== Biography ==
Born in [[Morteau]] around 1640, he became a [[novice]] in the [[Order of Saint Benedict|benedictine]] Saint-Maur congregation, and was ordained on March 20, 1663 in the Saint-Vincent de Besançon [[monastery]].<ref>[http://dictionnaire-journalistes.gazettes18e.fr/journaliste/318-casimir-freschot Dictionnaire des journalistes]</ref>
In 1674 he moved to Italy, first in [[Rome]], then in [[Bologna]], finally joining the [[Montecassino Congregation|benedictine congregation]] in [[Montecassino Abbey|Montecassino]]. Around 1700 he returned to the lay state and moved to the [[Netherlands]], in [[Utrecht]], where he earned a living teaching literature and history. During his stay in the Netherlands, he published (1706-1707) the monthly ''Entretiens sur les affaires du temps''.<ref>Joseph Marie Quérard, ''La France littéraire ou dictionnaire bibliographique des savants, historiens et gens de lettres de la France, ainsi que des littérateurs étrangers qui ont écrit en français, plus particulièrement pendant les XVIIIe et XIXe siècles''</ref> Having returned to France, Freschot was reintegrated as a monk in the Saint-Vanne congregation in 1718. He died in 1720, in the [[Luxeuil Abbey|Abbey of Luxeuil]].

{{Infobox museum | name = Composing hut of Gustav Mahler | native_name = Gustav Mahler-Komponierhäuschen | native_name_lang = | image = Mahler Composition Hut Klagenfurt.jpg | image_upright = | alt = | caption = image of 2008 | map_type = Austria | coordinates = {{coord|46|36|40.24|N|14|14|4.56|E|region:AT|display=inline,title}} | former_name = | established = {{Start date|1986|07|07|df=y}} | dissolved = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | location = Maiernigg, near [[Maria Wörth]] | type = biographical museum | accreditation = | collections = about [[Gustav Mahler]] | visitors = | founder = | director = | curator = | architect = Alfred Theuer | historian = | owner = | parking = | network = | website = }} The '''composing hut of Gustav Mahler''', German: '''Gustav Mahler-Komponierhäuschen''', is a little [[museum]] and [[memorial]] in Maiernigg, near [[Maria Wörth]] in [[Carinthia]], [[Austria]]. It is dedicated to the classical composer [[Gustav Mahler]] (1860-1911). In this hut he retreated from 1900 to 1907 in order to compose music. Since 7 July 1986 a permanent exhibition can be seen here.
There is also a [[Composing hut of Gustav Mahler (Attersee)|composing hut at the Attersee]], [[Upper Austria]],<ref>Georg Föttinger, [https://www.mahler-steinbach.at/english/composing-cottage/ Composing hut of Gustav Mahler Steinbach], Mahler Steinbach</ref> and one next to the [[Gustav Mahler Stube]] in [[South Tyrol]], [[Italy]].<ref>Frankfurter Algemeine, [http://www.faz.net/aktuell/reise/nah/gustav-mahler-in-toblach-flucht-vor-den-kuhgaesten-12143263.html Flucht vor den Kuhgästen], 9 April 2017 {{de icon}}</ref>
== Collection == In a display cabinet visitors can view material that remind of the composer, like photographs, original [[sheet music]], [[postcard]]s, letters<ref name="KLaL">Kärnten Lust am Leben, [https://archive.is/20170224130310/http://blog.kaernten.at/ausflugsziele/wanderung-zum-gustav-mahler-komponierhaeuschen/ Wanderung zum Gustav Mahler Komponierhäuschen] {{de icon}}</ref> and his death certificate. A bronze [[Bust (sculpture)|bust]] is placed in the room.<ref name="Pianoinstituut" /> Also a little library can be consulted there.<ref name="KLaL" />
Visitors can listen to Mahler's music, inside<ref name="KLaL" /> as well as outside the hut through loudspeakers.<ref name="Pianoinstituut">Pianoinstituut voor de Bommelerwaard, [http://www.pianoinstituut.nl/gustav-mahler-3.html Gustav Mahler] {{nl}}</ref> Since the renewal of 2016 also art expressions are allowed near the hut.<ref>Die Presse, [https://diepresse.com/home/leben/reise/5463721/In-Gustav-Mahlers-Komponierhaeuschen-am-Woerthersee In Gustav Mahlers Komponierhäuschen am Wörthersee], Madeleine Napetschnig, 14 July 2018 {{de icon}}</ref><ref>5 Minuten, [https://www.5min.at/201807154818/planeten-und-klangschalen-beim-gustav-mahler-haeuschen/ Planeten und Klangschalen beim Gustav-Mahler-Häuschen], 15 July 2018 {{de icon}}</ref>
{| style="float:left;" | [[File:Mahler Composition Hut Klagenfurt 5.jpg|center|150px]] | [[File:Ausstellung Komponierhaeuschen Mahler 01.jpg|226px]] |- | colspan="2" | <center>view in the museum (before the renewal of 2016)</center> |} {{Clearleft}}
== History == [[File:Maria Wörth Sekirn Wörthersee-Süduferstraße 23 Villa Siegel 30072004 01.jpg|thumb|left|150px|Villa Mahler]] Mahler came to Maiernigg in 1900 and had this composing hut built by Alfred Theuer from 1900 to 1901.<ref name="IGMS">International Gustav Mahler Society, [https://gustav-mahler.org/gedenkstaetten/maiernigg.cfm Maiernigg am Wörthersee (Kärnten)] {{de icon}}</ref> He retreated to this hut in order to compose music. At the time he was director and conductor of the court opera of [[Vienna]] (later the [[Vienna State Opera]]). The hut was of practical use for Mahler, because there was no time left for him to compose when he was in Vienna.<ref name="AI">National Austrian Bureau for Tourism, [https://views.austria.info/de/media?page=5&type=text#!/11507 Gustav Mahler (1860-1911) - Das Wichtigste in der Musik steht nicht in den Noten] {{de icon}}</ref> He called the hut ''Study auf dem Kogel''<ref name="KLaL" /><ref name="Pianoinstituut" />
In Maiernigg he completed his [[Symphony No. 4 (Mahler)|4th]], [[Symphony No. 5 (Mahler)|5th]], [[Symphony No. 6 (Mahler)|6th]], [[Symphony No. 7 (Mahler)|7th]] and parts of [[Symphony No. 8 (Mahler)|8th symphony]]. After his daughter Maria died on 12 July 1907, Mahler left his vacation home and went to Schluderbach in [[South Tyrol]], [[Italy]], where he spent the rest op his vacation.<ref name="IGMS" />
The composing hut was declared a [[cultural heritage]] in 1981. In 1985 it was renovated by the Gustav Mahler society from [[Klagenfurt]]. It was opened on 7 July 1986. This society does not exist any more and the composing hut is being maintained by the city of Klagenfurt. It was renewed in 2016.<ref name="IGMS" /> {{Clearleft}}
